body: I, as someone dipping my toes into it, imagines many of the devs here to be pretty damn smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities. I mean, the stuff you guys do is insane to me and many others and I look up to you devs in general because of this. Where did you guys even start?

title: What is it like being a programmer?

body: Programmer is vague calling everyone smart because of their profession...don't know about that. Like calling all doctors smart. But programming can be boring or interesting, its also very broad, programming making software, programming the web, programming in security etc...most times it can be mundane but its all about the job you take. If its a startup, no structure, from scratch it can be exciting, if its legacy code, maintenance, it could be boring. All in all if you just enjoy problem solving and working with any programming language, it can be rewarding. I work on the web side so more a developer than programmer but its all words to me...i would just say i started with getting involved with it/tech related groups in my area. I now steer clear from group-centric ones like 'blacks in tech' or 'women coders' or something, limits you in finding rational people...but yes that was a good move for me to just talk with other people in the field.

body:
I am a hobbyist but:

> Where did you guys even start?

[There is a big list of free programming books on Github](https://github.com/EbookFoundation/free-programming-books/blob/master/free-programming-books.md)

I started to type more ideas in detail but let me know if you would like me to try to give more ideas on what books specifically you might want to look at on that list

addendum: I guess there is also a sticky with resources, I didn't see the above link on there on a quick scan

post.title: What is it like being a programmer?

body:
I’ve met a lot of dumb programmers.
Shit programmers. 

Sometimes I feel like a fucking God, sometimes I feel like a fucking retard.

It’s cool to be able to know how to make apps and stuff cause it always amazes normies, but I feel like programming isn’t that hard it’s just intimidating as fuck.

It’s fun for me cause I like logic but it can be a real drag sometimes, it’s important to have passion projects

Like magic it becomes less insane when you know how it’s done, and the vast majority of programmers are building off of code and abstractions other people wrote. Then we use stack overflow and google to solve a lot of problems too.

I guess it’s like a once you see how sausage is made thing.

It’s interesting to be able to use apps and know why they have bugs, and how to fix them, but it also makes it frustrating cause you know someone got paid for that shit, like if it’s an app on the app store


EDIT: I started with game maker, then learned some C then started doing iOS apps in Objective C then it kinda ballooned from there.

After your first language it’s usually a lot easier to learn additional ones.

It can be really overwhelming at first but after a few years you can improve by a lot and be pretty competent.
body_html:
I’ve met a lot of dumb programmers. Shit programmers.

Sometimes I feel like a fucking God, sometimes I feel like a fucking retard.

It’s cool to be able to know how to make apps and stuff cause it always amazes normies, but I feel like programming isn’t that hard it’s just intimidating as fuck.

It’s fun for me cause I like logic but it can be a real drag sometimes, it’s important to have passion projects

Like magic it becomes less insane when you know how it’s done, and the vast majority of programmers are building off of code and abstractions other people wrote. Then we use stack overflow and google to solve a lot of problems too.

I guess it’s like a once you see how sausage is made thing.

It’s interesting to be able to use apps and know why they have bugs, and how to fix them, but it also makes it frustrating cause you know someone got paid for that shit, like if it’s an app on the app store

EDIT: I started with game maker, then learned some C then started doing iOS apps in Objective C then it kinda ballooned from there.

After your first language it’s usually a lot easier to learn additional ones.

It can be really overwhelming at first but after a few years you can improve by a lot and be pretty competent.

post.title: What is it like being a programmer?

body:
Embedded SW engineer here.

>What is it like being a programmer?

It's a pretty kooshy life. Sit in a cubical all day.  Pay is good.  Everyone at every level of employment has issues and stuff to complain about, but this has been a good life. You can find work anywhere, even at the bottom of a recession.  I highly recommend it if you can get the work. You need a degree for a lot of jobs. Your first job gets you your second. And there's an unlimited amount of work, we love more workers. There's so much god-damned stuff to do.     Well, competent ones. Shitty programmers just make more work for the rest of us. 

Honestly, engineering is just more paperwork. I kinda miss the days I could just make stuff instead of write about how to make stuff.

>I, as someone dipping my toes into it, imagines many of the devs here to be pretty damn smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities.

Eh. I like science. A lot of geeks and nerds do... geeky and nerdy stuff.  There's certainly a tone-shift when I hang out with people in the field vs... those "not of the tribe".   A lot of geeks are absolutely as bad the stereotype, being social retards. Some are dense and honestly not very good at being any type of programmer.

>Where did you guys even start?

Assembly. [A programming game](http://necrobones.com/atrobots/). Drive bots around and shoot each other. These days there's a bajillion different ways to get into the field. You could give [this little adorable game a try](https://alexnisnevich.github.io/untrusted/) for javascript. Or [constrained and distributed discrete signal processing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZkUHGvy2pNU).   Or just kick around a [easy-go-lucky language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malbolge).
body_html:
Embedded SW engineer here.

What is it like being a programmer?

It's a pretty kooshy life. Sit in a cubical all day. Pay is good. Everyone at every level of employment has issues and stuff to complain about, but this has been a good life. You can find work anywhere, even at the bottom of a recession. I highly recommend it if you can get the work. You need a degree for a lot of jobs. Your first job gets you your second. And there's an unlimited amount of work, we love more workers. There's so much god-damned stuff to do. Well, competent ones. Shitty programmers just make more work for the rest of us.

Honestly, engineering is just more paperwork. I kinda miss the days I could just make stuff instead of write about how to make stuff.

I, as someone dipping my toes into it, imagines many of the devs here to be pretty damn smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities.

Eh. I like science. A lot of geeks and nerds do... geeky and nerdy stuff. There's certainly a tone-shift when I hang out with people in the field vs... those "not of the tribe". A lot of geeks are absolutely as bad the stereotype, being social retards. Some are dense and honestly not very good at being any type of programmer.

Where did you guys even start?

Assembly. A programming game. Drive bots around and shoot each other. These days there's a bajillion different ways to get into the field. You could give this little adorable game a try for javascript. Or constrained and distributed discrete signal processing. Or just kick around a easy-go-lucky language.

body:
> smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities

Eh... You're a bit overboard with those pedestals you're putting people on. Just people solving puzzles. Like Sudoku. Except there's no pre-defined solution. It's just problem solving. 

> I mean, the stuff you guys do is insane to me and many others and I look up to you devs in general because of this. Where did you guys even start?

Inputs and outputs. What inputs do you need? How do you change those inputs? What outputs do you want? Understand the problem, solve, then implement. That and abstraction will get you a fairly decent way. Everything else is frameworks, tools, and hunting bugs.
body_html:
smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities

Eh... You're a bit overboard with those pedestals you're putting people on. Just people solving puzzles. Like Sudoku. Except there's no pre-defined solution. It's just problem solving.

I mean, the stuff you guys do is insane to me and many others and I look up to you devs in general because of this. Where did you guys even start?

Inputs and outputs. What inputs do you need? How do you change those inputs? What outputs do you want? Understand the problem, solve, then implement. That and abstraction will get you a fairly decent way. Everything else is frameworks, tools, and hunting bugs.

body:
Most languages share the same features: variables, functions, objects. Once you know a few, you can learn a new one in less than a week and write basic stuff. 

Try Python 3 if you want something easy to learn and powerful: http://python.org

post.title: What is it like being a programmer?

body: I started writing C++ for my high school robotics team. In college, I got more into web development, then after college I was hired as a sort of in between web developer/sysadmin/devops person. Just keep pushing yourself, keep studying, focus on growing your skill set and education, and you’ll get there.
body_html: I started writing C++ for my high school robotics team. In college, I got more into web development, then after college I was hired as a sort of in between web developer/sysadmin/devops person. Just keep pushing yourself, keep studying, focus on growing your skill set and education, and you’ll get there.

post.body: I, as someone dipping my toes into it, imagines many of the devs here to be pretty damn smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities. I mean, the stuff you guys do is insane to me and many others and I look up to you devs in general because of this. Where did you guys even start?
post.body_html: I, as someone dipping my toes into it, imagines many of the devs here to be pretty damn smart people compared to most others that excel at math, logic, and many other intellectual activities. I mean, the stuff you guys do is insane to me and many others and I look up to you devs in general because of this. Where did you guys even start?
post.title: What is it like being a programmer?

body:
Anything overly specialized can look incomprehensible (which makes the practitioners clearly unbelievably smart) to outsiders and newbies. 

Where I started was a kids' programming environment called Logo (well, before that I'd edit the gorilla game to make the bananas go faster or explode bigger, but I didn't know how to do much more than that). Searching on "turtle graphics environment" will probably bring up whatever the modern replacement is. 

What it's like now is... reading error messages and searching online. Or reading stack traces and then each piece of code they point to, for anything that "looks wrong" (which is intuition that comes from experience). 

When I was newer, there was a lot of taking problems apart until I had small enough pieces that I knew what to do with them. There's less of that now, just because I've had lots of practice and gotten faster at it. 

There's also quite a lot of reading documentation for whatever frameworks or libraries I'm working with or think might be useful, and lots of reading other documents explaining what needs to be built.

Anything overly specialized can look incomprehensible (which makes the practitioners clearly unbelievably smart) to outsiders and newbies.

Where I started was a kids' programming environment called Logo (well, before that I'd edit the gorilla game to make the bananas go faster or explode bigger, but I didn't know how to do much more than that). Searching on "turtle graphics environment" will probably bring up whatever the modern replacement is.

What it's like now is... reading error messages and searching online. Or reading stack traces and then each piece of code they point to, for anything that "looks wrong" (which is intuition that comes from experience).

When I was newer, there was a lot of taking problems apart until I had small enough pieces that I knew what to do with them. There's less of that now, just because I've had lots of practice and gotten faster at it.

There's also quite a lot of reading documentation for whatever frameworks or libraries I'm working with or think might be useful, and lots of reading other documents explaining what needs to be built.
